commentBody: I've started to notice, after 20 puzzles, that when you see Rebecca Goldstein's byline, you're going to get a solid, fair and smooth puzzle.  This one did not disappoint.
What an entertaining collection of gory-adjacent theme words! I enjoyed this one a lot.
37a makes no sense. GABE is the actor's name, not the role.
A good Wednesday puzzle.
Regarding the mini, do nervous travelers arrive "early" to the airport? Doesn't more time at the airport mean more waiting? Cautious travelers, maybe?

Cute theme, but more non-word three letter fill than I care for: TSA NSA IDK ESC OOO ATM RPI HMO DNA.

The intersection of DEADPOOL and BLOODBATH was fitting.

My hiccup was being slow to let go of SOLARECLIPSE.  Obviously, not knowing Chichen ITZA was an embarrassing deficiency in my store of knowledge.
Full of fun filler, alliteration from an English teacher. Enjoyable and rewarding
Such a fun puzzle!  An unusually enjoyable Wednesday.  Clever construction.

Yesterday's musical comments section has gotten me thinking about music in crosswords now apparently. Thanks TOTALECLIPSE (of the heart). Not mad to have that stuck in my head.

I ended with a few weird words in the east. Some crosses were just plain wrong, but others just didn't make sense with 29D. I know nothing about lures. REOTTERTAILS sure didn't look right. Left it anyway, because maybe? It slowed me down quite a bit.


I really enjoyed the theme on this one! Lots of fune fill too. Solid Wednesday.
I simply loved this puzzle! No more to say, except that it started my POY list for 2025.
DNF.  Couldn't let solarECLIPSE go...
So, how *do* you get ELFIN from "A little cute?" ?
Any puzzle with PATTI Luoone in it is okay by me. A fun Wednesday challenge. And did someone say BABKA? https://youtu.be/n0FLczlOpqo?si=ox1GQ5g_i_LRHcCi

I just turned off the t.v. after watching ‚Äì well, something, never mind.
A spooky puzzle, filled with gore, couldn't have been more appropriate.
If this is already Halloween, please tell me it's Halloween of 2029.

But, more importantly, it's a Rebecca Goldstein puzzle, so there's no way it isn't going to be great and hit all the right notes. 
Very satisfying and a wonderful mind cleanser!

Thank you, Rebecca!
Can someone explain the answer to 10 down ‚ÄúYou said it!‚Äù I feel like I should know this.

Nice, solid Wednesday‚Äîa little stretch here and there but no big problems. Thanks, Rebecca!

Liked the spooky theme, the Haunted Mansion is one of my favorite Disney attractions. Fortunately, they don't have any theming showing 7D, 20A, or 25D, though I wouldn't mind a 28D for refreshments.

Another example how a puzzle can range from easy to hard.

Had I thought TOTALECLIPSE I would have had a good time, though not record time, for a Wednesday.

Instead my mind went solidly to solarECLIPSE and I went way, way over the time.  In fact, because of that single error, I consider this the hardest Wednesday I can remember.

It was all based on one choice that I didn't see.  Had I seen it, it would have been easy.  But I didn't, so it was hard.
Anti-hero.
Enjoyed this puzzle especially because there were no clues involving the name of a celebrity.

Lots of brand new things for me:

ESPRINT, purely a French word, though the clue said nothing about French.

(I know, I know, it's part of the French language that's been adopted by English.  Still, *Wednesday*)

Also difficult:

ELFIN, ZOMBIEOFFICE, ROOSTERTAILS, ELLISA (never heard of anyone with that name), GHOSTKITCHEN (is that really a thing?  Seems  wildly inaccurate--the food preparers aren't ghosts and are just like any other kitchen).  GABE was difficult because Kotter was almost always referred to as "Kotter", and it's not common for an actor and character to have the same name.

I thought this very, very tricky, and that there will be a wide range of estimates on the difficulty.

Nice puzzle. I needed a few lookups along the Western edge (the campus and tv role).

I've had a somewhat interesting cultural and linguistic observation, too. In Polish a sweet braided bread is called "cha≈Çka", and it is of Jewish origins: you know it as challah or hallah. BABKA on the other hand is a traditional Easter cake. Apparently you call it pound cake. I can see online that Jews in this part of the world used to make challah from babka dough left over after the sabbath - perhaps that's why the American babka is our cha≈Çka?

The Southwest corner nearly did me in. Slow Wednesday for me.  I had to guess a few, which is not satisfying. That‚Äôs just me, though. I seem to recall enjoying Rebecca‚Äôs previous puzzles.

On a positive note, I‚Äôm back to 100 days on my streak. üéâ Illness caused me to lose my previous one.  Somehow I managed to keep this one going despite several days/nights of partying and carousing during Carnival! üíÉüèæ 

Toodles!
I liked this very much!! Cute grid and theme and I like the black square upside down crosses. My new personal best for Wednesday puzzles.

I was unable to face my patriotic duty, but I know there will be a full accounting tomorrow, so rather than do that now, I did this. 

A fine puzzle, no sleazy tricks, honest clues, worthy fills, just what I needed.  Even the little glue spots were clued with poise and unapologetic straightforwardness,  

Thank you, Rebecca Goldstein.  It was a pleasure to spend some time with a grownup professional. I would vote for this puzzle right now, and if it comes of for Wednesday of the year, I will vote for it then.

Strands Thread:


Strands #367
‚ÄúAhoy!‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµ


Chip in no spoilers until after the View All Replies button please. 

Cute.

Wow. I was so far off the constructor‚Äôs wavelength that I wasn‚Äôt even on the spectrum.  I have never heard of a ZOMBIE OFFICE,  GHOST KITCHEN or ROOSTER TAILS (in this context). I had ECLIPSE but guessed at ‚Äúsolar‚Äù. I thought the clever wit might be ‚Äúrapier‚Äù. I am aware of ‚ÄúRIT‚Äù, but not RPI. I always thought of ELFIN features as being small and sharp rather than cute. In short, this one wasn‚Äôt for me.

But that‚Äôs ok! Not every puzzle is for everyone. Maybe I‚Äôll have better reception tomorrow.
I was pondering the theme near the end of solving and realized SKELETON CREW would have made for a fun theme addition

I flew through some of this and struggled with a few other bits - INBOUNDS, PLATTE, ZOMBIE- , the famous people, the initialisms and the -TAILS. 
Really enjoyable.

Rebecca is such a pro.  I always perk up when I see her name, and today's puzzle was terrific as usual.  

[Source of a pulse] for SONAR was clever, and she squeezed in some interesting debuts as well with BLOOD BATH, ZOMBIE OFFICE, GHOST KITCHEN and KOMBUCHA.

Beautifully creepy puzzle.

So much I didn‚Äôt know,
so many forgiving crosses.

Felt like a perfect Wednesday.

Creamy with a bit of crunch!

Thank you Rebecca!

Have a lovely day all!
Both the Crossword and Strands puzzles have wonderfully creative grids. Even the Mini had a twist. A great puzzle day! Thanks to all the constructors!
LOVE this puzzle. One of my favorites in a long time. It helps that it‚Äôs my favorite ride. While I‚Äôm in line I hand out stickers to nearby kids.

I felt a shiver going down my spine when I filled in the theme revealer... a shiver of delight!

I loved the theme, loved the tricky clues, loved the house shape the theme answers made.

One of my favorite Wed puzzles this year!
I found this smooth as silk, v fun!

A little triggered by 53D,
but nice to finally get representation in the NYT puzzle.

Gotta like a puzzle that starts with AMIGO.

This is one tight theme set ‚Äì in-the-language phrases combining a Halloweeny term with a domicile area.  It‚Äôs easy to understand the odyssey Rebecca went through to come up with it.

Not only a tight theme, but the four theme answers shimmer with spark, with three of them never having appeared before in *any* of the major crossword venues, and the fourth (DEADPOOL) only a handful of times.

Rebecca needed an oversized grid to make it all work, but it worked beautifully. Look at the placement of the theme answers, truly, look at them!  Even though the set is not symmetrical, it feels so balanced and grounding.  Ahhh.

Those four longest downs are gorgeous: GHOST KITCHEN, ROOSTERTAILS, ZOMBIE OFFICE, and TOTAL ECLIPSE.

Sweet PuzzPair¬© of DEEP END and DEAD POOL.

Not only a fun solve, but an grid laced with all kinds of beauty.  This is so lovely, Rebecca.  Thank you!

A tougher than usual Tuesday for me, but ended up being a nice workout. The reveal was almost the last thing I worked out and then I had to go look at the referenced answers before it all finally dawned on me. That's a nice touch. 

Really different puzzle find today. I'll put that one in a reply. 

....
Enjoyed learning the thought processes of how this puzzle came to be.  Got stuck assembling the roof with my LoboS; took a while to sort that one out.  Well done and thanks.
could someone explain 11D to me? i can't figure out what it means

Thank you for a very fun puzzle.  I managed it without cheats, a thing that is becoming increasing rare for a Wednesday puzzle.
More, please!
Nice Wednesday. I came expecting to see some complaints about Roostertail, but I guess a lot of us took up fishing in the 1970‚Äôs.

Funny how the mind works.
I read the comments about GABE Kotter, and I went to GrABE and Jabberwocky.

‚ÄôTwas brillig, and the slithy toves
      Did gyre and gimble in the wabe:
All mimsy were the borogoves,
      And the mome raths outgrabe.

Today's puzzle was a good example of one where you read a clue and you think your answer fits, but you think it isn't right so you leave it blank and move on.
Sure enough, after getting some crossings or looking stuff up. BAM, your original answer was correct.

Nice one!

Why can't ghosts have babies? Because they have hollow weenies. 

I am donning a glove of garlic as this puzzle scared me.

Thank you Rebecca.  A fun Wednesday.
Interesting coincidence between 58D in this puzzle, and 41D in today‚Äôs New Yorker puzzle.  It‚Äôs almost like somebody somewhere sends out a secret message to crossword editors‚Ä¶
The middle left really tripped me up! CORE, GABE and ELISSA really left me scratching my head for a while, and the long down clue didn't help ü§£

So cute! And scary!

I can't hear Cat Stevens and not think of "Harold and Maude". Harold would have loved this puzzle!

Can you imagine the deli scene in a movie called "When Harold Met Maude"?
Its really hard to design a puzzle with a visual aspect like this. And to fill it with quality answers while avoiding junk is amazing. Great job Rebecca!

I'm surprised so many people seem to really like this one. For me it was a little blah, and a little easy for a Wednesday (my second fastest in the last 4 months [which is all the data I've synced with XW Stats]). But everyone has a different knowledge base -- if a few clues trip you up in the same part of the grid, the puzzle suddenly gets much more difficult!

I love spooky stories, and I loved this puzzle! I especially appreciate that the grid even looks like a HAUNTED MANSION. The theme was fun, but the fill was possibly more so: ROOSTER TAILS, PLATTE, BABKA, KOMBUCHA, and my personal favorite, TOTAL ECLIPSE. Here you go: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lcOxhH8N3Bo

I feel like a zombie today. Just back from "vacation". I love spending time with my family, but I'm a pitch-in-be-a-part-of-things grandma, so there was a lot of babysitting, driving, and homemaking involved. Plus I worked a total of 4 out fo the 7 weekdays I was away.  Wonderful time with the family, and time away from home, it was. Vacation, it ain't. Thanks for letting me rant.
Anyway, great puzzle!

In re: 11D...my mom--for decades--begged my dad to teach her to play bridge, ostensibly so that they could have bridge nights with friends. Of course she could have learned on her own, too, but I don't think gaining knowledge was really her point in asking. 

And I'm not sure if my dad's reluctance to teach her was due to his impatience with her, with bridge, or with the idea of having bridge nights with friends. In any case, he never did teach her, she never learned, and now, over the past 18 months, they've both passed away. 

If they had any regrets, such a small thing was probably not among them, but I hope, as the years go by and my partner and I retire and have more leisure time (god willing), that we both say "yes" often.

Original comment not published--too mean?
There were several clues I believe to be questionable; I questioned them.  Naughty, naughty.

Let's just say, "This one wasn't for me."  It was not diffiicult, but neither did it hold interest for me, with the exception of 29D--which wasn't even part of the theme.  I am not sure why this wasn't held for Halloween.

Possibly I'm a tiny bit cross because high winds made sleep difficult, not to mention joint pain from many hours on my feet  yesterday (and more to come today.)  Alas, it is not possible to mark a quilt border without standing over a table for hours...
today's Strands was fun, visually very cool!
The tricky clues are almost always the ones I had already figured out‚Ä¶ but then I‚Äôm left trying to figure out what I missed!

Okay, I have a science fiction reader's understanding of the theory of relativity, so I'm not sure how the 1919 event confirmed it. Did the Moon get closer to or farther from the Earth as it passed in front of the Sun? Did it lose inertia as it was affected by the relative gravitational fields of the two larger bodies? Am I even close?

Nice, fun, chewy puzzle. Just right for a Wednesday. The middle left gave me some problems (I had never heard of 25D), but eventually, it all worked out. The representation of the haunted mansion was wonderful. Better to enjoy this puzzle now than wait for next Halloween.

Congrats to the constructor -- let's have more from her!
Nice puzzle. Would have been cooler in October. I'm not sure what Deadpool has to do with Haunted Mansion?

I wasn‚Äôt a fan of TSA and NSA being right next to each other‚Ä¶ but considering there were 26(!!) three-letter entries, things like that are inevitable, I suppose.

Also is that a creepy clown face in the grid‚Äôs negative space?
I'm sure I'm not the first to notice this, but did anyone else think that the grid today IMAGED Pennywise, the clown from Stephen King's "It"?

Terrific (if not quite terrifying) Wednesday.

Sailed through until I was derailed, like so many others, by the darn SOLAR ECLIPSE.  I knew ALM was wrong, but had to walk away and return with fresh eyes to see ATM.  Then a couple more tweaks and the happy music played!

Thanks for a much needed respite from the insanity of the world right now.

Hmm.  Looks as  if someone went for "GHOULISH" but ended up "FOOLISH."

ESPRIT = "Clever wit"???  Um, no.

"Small contribution" = ADD IN.  Srsly?  Maybe an ADD-ON

IN BOUNDS....INBOUNDS....IN-BOUNDS? = "Puts into play"?  Does this make sense?  "And he inbounds the ball immediately"--said nobody, ever.

IDK where some of this originated, but it belongs in the 7D.

However, I was very pleased to enter ROOSTER TAILS-- we caught a lot of bass using those lures!  They especially liked the silver ones.

I guess I'm a visually oriented person (I loved the Strands solution today), and I also love puzzles like this where the themers are both across and down answers.  And I loved DEADPOOL crossing BLOODBATH  --forms a cross to ward off vampires.

Can‚Äôt believe they spent this great puzzle on a random day in March instead of saving for Halloween! 

Breezed through in about 10 minutes only to then be completely stymied by the lower left side for another 20!
OOO?

I always appreciate and love when there‚Äôs a theme so definitely great work there! However; I‚Äôm confused about the ‚ÄúOOO‚Äù answer. The clue/hint doesn‚Äôt seem to add up to it. Or maybe I just don‚Äôt get it?! I‚Äôm used to being the black sheep in most situations lol! Namaste!!
After all the solarECLIPSE comments, I feel quite lucky that I got to ITZA before that down. I think I would've ended up in that same trap.

Fun theme, AND the theme answers look sort of like a (headless) skeleton when highlighted! I‚Äôd ask why this wasn‚Äôt saved for October, but I‚Äôm currently wearing skeleton-print pants in March, so clearly I‚Äôm in agreement that spooky themes are appropriate year round.
Spent too much time being convinced that it was a "solar" eclipse rather than a "total" eclipse.

The two upside-down crucifixes seem appropriate to the theme. üôÇ

Surprised that I haven‚Äôt seen an outpouring of rage directed against that, ala the supposed ‚Äúswastika‚Äù grid on Holocaust Remembrance Day last year. 

Maybe people are lightening up in regards to minutiae when confronted with actual crises.
Very tough (for me). Had to research Chichen ITZA to get the left side going‚Ä¶
Nice Wednesday puzzle! Fun theme! An enjoyable solve!

almost a personal best, despite not knowing babka, and never hearing the name elissa.  Also don't associate esprit with clever wit, but whomever.  Now I have to look up how an eclipse confirmed theory of relativity.  Theme was a big help with ghostkitchen and zombieoffice, unfamiliar terms.
An interesting puzzle with an unusual geometry. The pair of black inverted crosses seemed nicely thematic.

In my relatively short time doing NYT crosswords, I've come to recognize Rebecca Goldstein's name from the get-go and look forward to some fun. Today did not disappoint! What a fun and spooooooky puzzle! I've never heard of a ZOMBIEOFFICE, but it makes a lot of sense and I like it! It also came pretty smoothly for me as the crosses were all very reasonable, I thought. The organization that restructured me out after 20 years (shortly before the pandemic), is most certainly that now. Big, shiny beautiful building they bought downtown just a couple of years before the pandemic‚Äîwhen they had very little latitude for remote work, now sits empty. Crazy! Glad there's a name for it! (And sooooo glad, hard as it was at the time, that I came out wayyyyyyyy for the better from my being restructured out!. ANDHOW!) Anyhow, had fun thinking through the characters on Welcome Back Kotter, an old favorite of mine. I was hoping the role answer would be Epstein's mother (har!), but alas, no. (Insert Horschack laugh here.) Better yet, here's a clip of it: https://vlipsy.com/vlip/welcome-back-kotter-horshack-laugh-TGK2P5TT Last somewhat random thought, every time the title appears even slightly, I consider it my sacred duty to share this literal version of Bonnie Tyler's Total Eclipse of the Heart! Best 5 minutes and 33 seconds of my life... well, maybe not *the* best, but it's up there. :-) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XMmXCyrV_WQ
I had ZOOMIEOFFICE for a while and couldn't figure out how it fit with the theme lol

Fun one, thx. Several folks have posted videos of TOTAL ECLIPSE of the heart (I responded twice with the flowchart version). Christina Bianco is a singing actress with an amazing ear for impressions, and her go-to party trick is Total Eclipse in the voices of 10-20 different divas. Here's an older version, from the Ellen show: https://youtu.be/73Y_Vp1IAfY?t=75 Believe it or not, several of my faves are missing from this version--PATTI LuPone, Bernadette Peters, Judy Garland, Bette Midler, Edith Piaf, Shirley Bassey... you never know who's going to come out of her mouth.
Anyone else at Disney World today? I finished the crossword, and in line right now for Haunted Mansion, wearing my Haunted Mansion shirt!  A serendipitous theme!

ELFIN had me scratching my head, but otherwise a fun puzzle. Learned a few things too! Always up for a spooky theme, but as a stickler for seasonal propriety, I would have appreciated this more in October!
Great puzzle! I'm still puzzled by AND HOW, though.
Excellent puzzle.
I‚Äôd never heard of ‚ÄòElissa‚Äô before, but today she‚Äôs been in the news all day!
Ah, Rebecca, you always deliver. Delightful Wednesday...neither too easy nor too hard...a veritable crossword bubble bath! Grazie!
I positively loved this theme!
The only thing this puzzle lacks is a couple of witches: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pTshgTqdz14 Or maybe some Klaus Nomi: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HmLk2vSXXtk
I had three big mistakes. Like I had "space" not "office". Through me off so badly. But I got there.
Lots of fun, no matter the time of year. Thanks, Rebecca üòä
Computers are also "imaged".
I put SOLAR instead of TOTAL and that took a little to patch up. But a good Wednesday one.

I didn't get caught in the "SOLAR eclipse" trap that many did,  because I couldn't possibly forget "Chichen Itza" after having seen the Backyardigans' "Chichen Itza Pizza" episode many times when my daughter was young! (We loved the Backyardigans...)
I thought ZOMBIEOFFICE was ZOOMOFFICE at first. I had ATM as a cross. Things were not fitting! Spent too long on 25D.
Great puzzle Rebecca! I really enjoyed completing this one!  As a lover of both hot tea and iced tea, I must confess to not having ever heard of Kombucha.  But now I at least know how to spell it!

I enjoyed this one, but also didn't understand why ELFIN was an answer.  Oh well.  I've heard of the Platte River (even as a Canadian ;‚Å†) but I am a geography fan.  Recently, I saw an episode of the British quiz show Pointless (on YouTube) about British rivers - not so much an expert on that.  But, it's good to keep learning - you never know when it'll be useful in something like a crossword!
I think BABKA is more rolled than braided, but ok I guess. Fun puzzle anyway
Maybe a little pedantic, but I must point out that Cat Stevens is also an ‚Äúadopted‚Äù name. Needed a parenthetical!
Welcome Back Cotter name, Itza, Elissa all in the same corner. Why not complete it with something like ‚ÄúBort‚Äù and convince everyone that it‚Äôs not actually all that uncommon?

@Steve L 

Ms Goldstein had an AVCX puzzle about 18 months ago called ‚ÄúFake Meatl that was one of my favorite puzzles ever. I‚Äôve enjoyed many of her other puzzles, too.

@Steve L 

IMHO, it was only smooth if you managed to avoid a couple of horrible booby traps, like TOTALECLIPSE and ELFIN.

@Steve L And speaking of top constructors, Robyn Weintraub has an easy Wednesday offering at the New Yorker today. https://www.newyorker.com/puzzles-and-games-dept/crossword/2025/03/05 The first Robyn of spring?

@cfmoore 
it's both, Gabe Kaplan played Gabe Kotter.
@cfmoore Gabe was the character‚Äôs name as well.

@cfmoore

GABE was also the character‚Äôs name.
@cfmoore The role was Gabe Kotter, played by Gabe Kaplan.
@cfmoore Kotter's wife always referred to him as Gabe.
@Scott I came here to make the exact same comment.

@Francis 

It was brand new to me, too, but I thought it was pretty easy to infer.

@Graham Hackett Depends on what they're nervous of.  

My mom was nervous about being late. We always got to the airport hours early -- and this was in the 80s!

@Steve L 

Nice.  Sounds like a good trip.

@CCed 
I don't know much about lures either, but the word feathered in the clue, along with the crosses I had, made ROOSTERTAILS seem reasonable.

@CCed 

Oh, wow, a fishing lure! Haha, I was way off but it led me to the answer. Love when that happens!

@sotto voce 

Ah, that‚Äôs why it doesn‚Äôt work. No feathers.
@CCed TOTAL ECLIPSE of the heart is infinitely improved by a flowchart. ;) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I5HrsZFdfh8

@Bob T. 

Holy moly! I'd use a less cheesy word if NYT would let me. That is amazing. Thank you for sharing. I love it.

@Tim Carey 

Yeah.  I toke me forever to see that too.  I was so invested with solarECLIPSE that I was totally stymied for about a half hour just on those few squares.
@Tim Carey Same.

@Tim Carey 
I know that DNF can be used in multiple contexts, but you are not, by chance, a Geocacher, are you? üòä
@Violet. Metaphorically. I can recall Audrey Hepburn being described thus.
@Violet I think it‚Äôs something along the lines of ‚Äúlittle and cute‚Äù. She was both little and cute: she was elfin.

@Violet 

That was a *really* nasty clue.  One of my least favorites of all time.  

Especially given that the current foremost literature on elves is from Tolkien, and Tolkien's elves were tall and beautiful, not "cute".

I guess we should have been thinking of Keebler elves.

@Francis 

Tolkien's elves were "elven".

"Elfin" was invented by Edmund Spenser in "The Faerie Queene", and Tolkien seems to have rather despised the word on philological grounds.
It's funny how everyone seems to have latched on to Tolkien's "dwarves", which he specifically noted was not the correct plural of "dwarf" in English, but that "elven", a really useful alternative know that  "elfin" has wandered off to a new meaning, has been largely ignored.

@Linda Jo 

To be fair, the puzzle didn‚Äôt put it in that context.

@sotto voce 
Whatever show you were watching you should have changed the channel. There was plenty of good news all around.

@Hanson 

Yeah, as long as you're a billionaire.  Or a billionaires's mark.

@Hanson 

Helps if you don't give a flip about anyone other than yourself.

@Miker 

It's an emphatic agreement, probably a bit dated.
@Miker "Boy that movie sure was scary!" "And how!" Just a phrase of emphatic agreement.

@JayTee 

Yeah, it's like Leave it to Beaver language!
@MikerI remember it from the Little Rascals reruns from so many years ago
@Bill in Yokohama - It brings me back to the Little Rascals. They said it a lot, and how!
@Miker It's a bit dated. I most recently encountered it in the lyrics to "Wicked."
@Linda Jo or the flowchart version... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I5HrsZFdfh8
@Jason says the person named after one üòÄüòÄ

@Linda Jo 

That‚Äôs what I think. The names we‚Äôre familiar with don‚Äôt even register as names. It‚Äôs only when we hit one we don‚Äôt know that we get testy about them.

@Francis 

I had definitely never seen it spelled that way until Elissa Slotkin was elected. It helped that the first M name that came to mind for me was Melissa.

@Francis 

Ghost kitchens are delivery/take out only restaurants (sort of). Reddit was discussing that the other day, and someone mentioned that a Denny's, a chain restaurant, was doubling as a ghost kitchen, doing delivery under a different name, while still doing the typical Denny's menu for their regular customers. The "ghost" part of it is that there is no listed "official" location most of the time, especially when delivery only.

@JayTee 

That's so weird. Under Polish law, every business has to publicly declare its place of operation, for the benefit of consumers filing complains, as well as to let the sanitary authorities know where to go to check sanitary conditions.

@Francis 
There has been some scandal over 'ghost' kitchens here. One reason is that very poorly paid 'chefs' mass-prepare food in what are cramped badly-ventilated unregulated makeshift huts on industrial estates, when customers think they are getting food prepared in the actual restaurant kitchen.

@Andrzej
I‚Äôm sure they must still register with the Health Department and get inspections, but I can see how it could get tricky. There are probably different regulations in each state as well. Such as how restaurants in some states must publicly post their Health Department Inspection Ratings, but this is not required in all states.
@Francis Re: actors who play characters with the same name - Roseanne Barr, Lucille Ball, Jerry Seinfeld, and Ray Romano all come to mind. I‚Äôm sure there are others.

@CrispyShot 

Mary Tyler Moore, Reba McEntire, Bob Newhart, Tim Allen‚Ä¶

@Steve L  @Crispy Shot

I‚Äôd have saved myself some time if I had read your replies before posting my own. You‚Äôd think I‚Äôd have learned by now.

@Andrzej 

BABKA here is more cake than bread, with seams of chocolate or cinnamon rubbing through it, making it quite sweet. It‚Äôs very good with coffee. 

BABKA is traditionally made with leftover challah dough, which is one of the sweetest bread doughs. Like challah, it is braided before baking. 

BABKA was developed in Eastern Europe, but the chocolate version is almost certainly an American invention, as chocolate wasn‚Äôt available in Eastern Europe at the time.

@Andrzej BABKA and challah are two different types of bread, both with Jewish origins. BABKA is braided, but in a subtle way: the adjective that most readily comes to mind is *swirled*. (This clue annoyed me a lot!). It is delicious. And much more sweet than challah... @Lea 
"Two hearts" is a BID in card games like bridge.
@Linda Jo And the bids range from one club to seven no trump. I play bridge a few hours every day, and trust me, 7 no trump might come up twice a year.
@Tony thank you!

@Lea 
It took me a minute to "get it"....part of healthy amnesia.  

Our Granny and Grandpa were avid card players who had regular "bridge evenings"--sometimes coming home Not Speaking over a misplay or bad BID.  
Granny decided she would teach my sister and me how to play bridge; after an hour we were so thoroughly confused and flummoxed that we swore off bridge forever!  The End 
(A worse teacher was never born....)

@Lea My parents played bridge - a lot.  The women, every Tuesday afternoon, the couples, Saturday nights.  The number of evenings I sat somewhere nearby, hearing them thoughtfully intoning, "Two hearts", "Pass", and so on, is countless.  I failed to learn to like or play bridge, but I absorbed that bit of arcana - just for this puzzle, I guess!

@Lea 
The BID of "two hearts" means the opening bidder believes they can take at least two tricks, with hearts as trump. Subsequent bidders must go higher than that to establish trump, and who leads play.

@Marcia Fidler 

"no Trump" is becoming a more common bid in bridge these days.  And the rallying cry of easily half of Americans.

Grant,

At least eight tricks.



And I haven't played since 1970.

@Linda Jo As an 8th grade history and language arts teacher, I taught diagramming sentences. One activity I did was to divide the class into groups of four and have them diagram "Twas brillig. . . outgrabe." So much fun!

@Marcia Fidler I love a good sentence diagram. As a college comp teacher, I had my students spend an entire 75-minute class diagramming a single sentence from Foucault.
